title: Confidence rocked in tech stocks after short-selling raid on WiseTech
text:
Meanwhile, shares in Afterpay have also come under pressure after it emerged last week that the Reserve Bank of Australia was reviewing the company's no-surcharge rule, which prevented retailers from passing on its costs to customers.

Chris Prunty, at investment firm QVG Capital, said the declines in Afterpay and WiseTech were specific to those companies but there were broader forces at work that resulted in investors selling down high-growth tech stocks.

"Part of the sell-off is because there’s a floor under global interest rates and interest rates have stopped falling," he said, citing a higher probability of an outcome on Brexit and a "mini" trade deal between China and the United States.

Growth deficit

"The fact the world and global growth has the potential to improve means interest rates won't be quite as low as what they were, and that hurts high PE [price to earnings] companies."

But he said interest rates remained low in an absolute sense so it was "not the time to panic on higher valuation names".

Ben McGarry of Sydney-based hedge fund Totus Capital said local investors were clamouring for growth stocks and driving up valuations. Goldman Sachs research showed companies that were increasing their earnings by more than 20 per cent were twice as expensive as they were in other markets.

“If you have a great theme like technology, you only have a small number of quality names in our market so you get this phenomenon of a lot of money squeezing into small doors," Mr McGarry said.

Advertisement

"That’s why you get these valuation discrepancies.”

Investors globally are re-assessing valuations of high growth stocks, particularly after the poor performance of recent listings Uber, Lyft and Slack and the catastrophic fallout from the failed initial public offering of WeWork.

Short attack

Sharemarket floats have also been pulled in Australia. This week, private equity-backed online classified group PropertyGuru became the third float in a week to be pulled.

"As an investor, you cannot have pricing if you don’t have confidence in the quality of the business and the earnings," said Mr Prunty.

"For the right IPO, the market would be supportive. It all just comes down to quality of business."

Mr Prunty said short reports could be right for the wrong reasons and the falls in Corporate Travel, which has also been targeted, and WiseTech, could have "as much to do with their performance as the content of the reports".

"Arguably, at the time, both stocks were trading at quite high premiums to their own trading history, and the [broader] market, and were vulnerable."

Mr McGarry would not disclose whether Totus Capital was shorting WiseTech but said the stock attracted interest from short-sellers because of its "high valuation and an unconventional method of growth which is different to other types of software companies”.
description: The company has become the largest Australian target of an activist short report after losing just over a fifth of its $10 billion valuation.
